title: Hardhat throws a strange error when trying to call smart contract functions
body:
# Hardhat throws a strange error when trying to call smart contract functions
## Description:
When trying to call a smart contract function running on hardhat, it throws confusing errors. (All of this has been tested on the cheapETH network with no errors.)

## Environment:
OS: Manjaro linux 5.10.42
Ver: 2.3.0

## Steps to reproduce:
1. Deploy this smart contract to the hardhat network:
```
pragma solidity 0.8.0;

contract CoolNumber {
    int8 coolNumber = 0;
    
    function GetCoolNumber() public view returns (int8) {
        return coolNumber;
    }
    
    function SetCoolNumber(int8 n) public {
        coolNumber = n;
    }
}
```
2. Compile and then deploy the smart contract
3. Run this python script with ABI.py in the same folder:

**main.py**
```
import web3
from ABI import abi
import time

Web3 = web3.Web3

polling_interval = 5
address = '0x5FbDB2315678afecb367f032d93F642f64180aa3' # replace this with the smart contract address


def main():
    w3 = Web3(Web3.HTTPProvider("http://127.0.0.1:8545"))
    contract = w3.eth.contract(address=address, abi=abi)
    while True:
        x = contract.functions.GetCoolNumber().call()
        print(x)
        time.sleep(polling_interval)


if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
```
**ABI.py**
```
abi = [
    {
        "inputs": [
            {
                "internalType": "int8",
                "name": "n",
                "type": "int8"
            }
        ],
        "name": "SetCoolNumber",
        "outputs": [],
        "stateMutability": "nonpayable",
        "type": "function"
    },
    {
        "inputs": [],
        "name": "GetCoolNumber",
        "outputs": [
            {
                "internalType": "int8",
                "name": "",
                "type": "int8"
            }
        ],
        "stateMutability": "view",
        "type": "function"
    }
]
```
4. Alternatively in the hardhat console type `const coolNumber = await (await ethers.getContractFactory("CoolNumber")).attach("0x5FbDB2315678afecb367f032d93F642f64180aa3")`
5. Then type: `await coolNumber.GetCoolNumber()` but replace the address with the contract address.

## Actual behaviour:
In hardhat console when trying to call `GetCoolNumber()`:

## Logs:
In the hardhat node logs:
```
eth_call
  WARNING: Calling an account which is not a contract
  From: 0xf39fd6e51aad88f6f4ce6ab8827279cfffb92266
  To:   0x5fbdb2315678afecb367f032d93f642f64180aa3
```

As the warning says, you are making an `eth_call` in an account with no code. That usually happens when you use two different instances of the hardhat network. For example, if you have a script that deploys the contract and another that uses the contract, and you do `hh run deploy.js && hh run useContract.js`, each script will create, use and destroy a temporary, in-process hardhat network.

Another typical reason people get this error is when they start a node with `hh node` in one terminal and run their script in another terminal by doing `hh run useContract.js` instead of `hh run --network localhost useContract.js`.

I'm going to close this because it's very unlikely this is a bug. Please use [our discord server](https://hardhat.org/discord) if you have more questions about this.

> So where is the network that the first deployment command points to?

When you don't specify a network, the execution will be done in a temporary, in-process Hardhat Network that is created and destroyed with your command.

This is useful, for example, when you are running your tests. Otherwise you would have to do something like "start a node in one terminal, run `hh test --network localhost` in another terminal, then kill the node in the first one". You can think about the in-process Hardhat Network as a shortcut for that (there are other subtle differences though, like the fact that there's no HTTP involved).

This is an interesting issue that I'm facing currently. What I'm doing is forking BSC like this
`npx hardhat node --fork https://bsc-dataseed2.binance.org`
running a command via `npx hardhat run --network localhost final\ganache.js`

It's weird - the code in ganache.js does not change. Sometimes the script passes without any issues and sometimes the node gives out the warnings which fails the script. I believe this is still an ongoing issue on HH - I still cannot figure out exactly what is causing the issue, but it's still there.
